newsitem.title: NORWAY: Norway says Israeli-PLO talks big step forward.
newsitem.headline: Norway says Israeli-PLO talks big step forward.

text.p: Norway said on Wednesday it expected Israeli and PLO leaders to discuss a range of issues from Hebron to border closures in their talks over the next few days in a "major and significant" effort to revive the peace process.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet Palestinian President Yasser Arafat at Erez, the Israeli-Gaza crossing point, at 5.30 p.m. (1430 GMT), PLO negotiator Saeb Erekat told reporters in Palestinian-ruled Gaza.
"I just talked to Arafat," Norwegian Foreign Minister Bjoern Tore Godal told Reuters in an interview. "I see this as a major and significant step forward in the peace process."

"Of course, it is not a breakthrough in itself but it is important because it creates a psychological climate betwen the two leaders that is very instrumental in the future negotiations," the foreign minister said.
Norway, which helped broker the 1993 Israeli-PLO peace pact, has been involved in new diplomatic efforts in recent weeks to ease relations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation.
"I have reason to believe the agenda in the next few days will be the border closures, the issue of Hebron and the special security issues in the region."
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been struggling over the past week to find a formula that would enable the two men to meet and for full-fledged peace talks to resume.
Netanyahu, elected in May on a pledge not to swap occupied Arab land for peace, had said originally he preferred not to meet Arafat but softened his position in recent days.
Palestinians have been pressing for a summit and resumed talks to tackle the issue of Israel's long-delayed troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.

Norway, which hosted 14 secret meetings between Israeli and PLO negotiators in 1993, has again been working behind the scenes, overseeing fresh talks between key Israeli and Palestinian personalities in a private Tel Aviv apartment.
The new discussions have been held under the guidance of United Nations special envoy Terje Larsen, a Norwegian, and his wife Mona Juul, a diplomat at the Norwegian embassy.
"We take pleasure in being used for the benefit of the peace process," said Godal, who will meet Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussaa on Thursday in Oslo.
Moussa arrives on Wednesday evening for talks with Godal and Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland.

Godal said his Middle East adviser Ambassador Rolf Trolle Andersen found during a visit to Israel and Gaza this summer just after the Israeli election that the new Israeli leaders were very interested in the peace process.

"We were positively surprised at the keen interest that representatives of the new Israeli government showed in the nature and psychology of the peace process so far," he said. "They were not too acquainted with the details, but then they had not been directly involved in the mechanisms and the personalities on the Palestinian side."
